column2: Although the first two chapters of this new history have been devoted to the fortunes and personal attributes of Lady Eustace, the historian begs his readers not to believe that that opulent and aristocratic Becky Sharp is to assume the dignity of heroine in the forthcoming pages.
column3: Although the first two chapters of this new history have been devoted to the fortunes and personal attributes of Lady Eustace, the historian begs his readers not to believe that that opulent and aristocratic Becky Sharp is to assume the dignity of heroine in the forthcoming pages.

column2: That there shall be any heroine the historian will not take upon himself to assert; but if there be a heroine, that heroine shall not be Lady Eustace.

column2: Poor Lizzie Greystock!--as men double her own age, and who had known her as a forward, capricious, spoilt child in her father's lifetime, would still call her.
column3: Poor Lizzie Greystock!--as men double her own age, and who had known her as a forward, capricious, spoilt child in her father's lifetime, would still call her.

column2: She did so many things, made so many efforts, caused so much suffering to others, and suffered so much herself throughout the scenes with which we are about to deal, that the story can hardly be told without giving her that prominence of place which has been assigned to her in the last two chapters.
column3: She did so many things, made so many efforts, caused so much suffering to others, and suffered so much herself throughout the scenes with which we are about to deal, that the story can hardly be told without giving her that prominence of place which has been assigned to her in the last two chapters.

column2: Nor does the chronicler dare to put forward Lucy Morris as a heroine. The real heroine, if it be found possible to arrange her drapery for her becomingly, and to put that part which she enacted into properly heroic words, shall stalk in among us at some considerably later period of the narrative, when the writer shall have accustomed himself to the flow of words, and have worked himself up to a state of mind fit for the reception of noble acting and noble speaking.
column3: Nor does the chronicler dare to put forward Lucy Morris as a heroine. column2: Lucy Morris certainly was a treasure,--a treasure though no heroine. She was a sweetly social, genial little human being whose presence in the house was ever felt to be like sunshine.

column2: She was quite resolved to be somebody among her fellow-creatures,--not somebody in the way of marrying a lord or a rich man, or somebody in the way of being a beauty, or somebody as a wit; but somebody as having a purpose and a use in life.

column2: It was her fault that she had nothing of feminine vanity.

column2: But no man or woman was ever more anxious to be effective, to persuade, to obtain belief, sympathy, and co-operation;--not for any result personal to herself, but because, by obtaining these things, she could be effective in the object then before her, be it what it might.
column3: But no man or woman was ever more anxious to be effective, to persuade, to obtain belief, sympathy, and co-operation;--not for any result personal to herself, but because, by obtaining these things, she could be effective in the object then before her, be it what it might.

column2: One other thing may be told of her.
column3: One other thing may be told of her.

column2: She had given her heart,--for good and all, as she owned to herself,--to Frank Greystock.
column3: She had given her heart,--for good and all, as she owned to herself,--to Frank Greystock.

column2: She had owned to herself that it was so, and had owned to herself that nothing could come of it.
column3: She had owned to herself that it was so, and had owned to herself that nothing could come of it.

column2: Frank was becoming a man of mark,--but was becoming a man of mark without much money.
column3: Frank was becoming a man of mark,--but was becoming a man of mark without much money.

column2: Of all men he was the last who could afford to marry a governess.
column3: Of all men he was the last who could afford to marry a governess.

column2: And then, moreover, he had never said a word to make her think that he loved her.
column3: And then, moreover, he had never said a word to make her think that he loved her.

column2: He had called on her once or twice at Fawn Court,--as why should he not?
column3: He had called on her once or twice at Fawn Court,--as why should he not?

column2: Seeing that there had been friendship between the families for so many years, who could complain of that?
column3: Seeing that there had been friendship between the families for so many years, who could complain of that?

column2: Lady Fawn, however, had--not complained, but just said a word.
column3: Lady Fawn, however, had-not complained, but just said a word.

column2: A word in season, how good is it?
column3: A word in season, how good is it?

column2: Lucy did not much regard the word spoken to herself; but when she reflected that a word must also have been spoken to Mr. Greystock,--otherwise how should it have been that he never came again?--that she did not like.
column3: Lucy did not much regard the word spoken to herself; but when she reflected that a word must also have been spoken to mr Greystock,--otherwise how should it have been that he never came again?--that she did not like.

column2: In herself she regarded this passion of hers as a healthy man regards the loss of a leg or an arm.
column3: In herself she regarded this passion of hers as a healthy man regards the loss of a leg or an arm.

column2: It is a great nuisance, a loss that maims the whole life,--a misfortune to be much regretted.
column3: It is a great nuisance, a loss that maims the whole life,--a misfortune to be much regretted.

column2: But because a leg is gone, everything is not gone.
column3: But because a leg is gone, everything is not gone.

column2: A man with a wooden leg may stump about through much action, and may enjoy the keenest pleasures of humanity.
column3: A man with a wooden leg may stump about through much action, and may enjoy the keenest pleasures of humanity.

column2: He has his eyes left to him, and his ears, and his intellect.
column3: He has his eyes left to him, and his ears, and his intellect.

column2: He will not break his heart for the loss of that leg.
column3: He will not break his heart for the loss of that leg.

column2: And so it was with Lucy Morris.
column3: And so it was with Lucy Morris.

column2: She would still stump about and be very active.
column3: She would still stump about and be very active.

column2: Eyes, ears, and intellect were left to her.
column3: Eyes, ears, and intellect were left to her.

column2: Looking at her position, she told herself that a happy love could hardly have been her lot in life.
column3: Looking at her position, she told herself that a happy love could hardly have been her lot in life.

column2: Lady Fawn, she thought, was right.
column3: Lady Fawn, she thought, was right.

column2: A governess should make up her mind to do without a lover.
column3: A governess should make up her mind to do without a lover.

column2: She had given away her heart, and yet she would do without a lover.
column3: She had given away her heart, and yet she would do without a lover.

column2: When, on one dull, dark afternoon, as she was thinking of all this, Lord Fawn suddenly put into her hands a cruelly long printed document respecting the Sawab, she went to work upon it immediately.
column3: When, on one dull, dark afternoon, as she was thinking of all this, Lord Fawn suddenly put into her hands a cruelly long printed document respecting the Sawab, she went to work upon it immediately.

column2: As she read it, she could not refrain from thinking how wonderfully Frank Greystock would plead the cause of the Indian prince, if the privilege of pleading it could be given to him.
column3: As she read it, she could not refrain from thinking how wonderfully Frank Greystock would plead the cause of the Indian prince, if the privilege of pleading it could be given to him.

column2: The spring had come round, with May and the London butterflies, at the time at which our story begins, and during six months Frank Greystock had not been at Fawn Court.
column3: The spring had come round, with May and the London butterflies, at the time at which our story begins, and during six months Frank Greystock had not been at Fawn Court.

column2: Then one day Lady Eustace came down with her ponies, and her footman, and a new dear friend of hers, Miss Macnulty.
column3: Then one day Lady Eustace came down with her ponies, and her footman, and a new dear friend of hers, Miss Macnulty.

column2: While Miss Macnulty was being honoured by Lady Fawn, Lizzie had retreated to a corner with her old dear friend Lucy Morris.
column3: While Miss Macnulty was being honoured by Lady Fawn, Lizzie had retreated to a corner with her old dear friend Lucy Morris.

column2: It was pretty to see how so wealthy and fashionable a woman as Lady Eustace could show so much friendship to a governess.
column3: It was pretty to see how so wealthy and fashionable a woman as Lady Eustace could show so much friendship to a governess.

column2: Have you seen Frank, lately? said Lady Eustace, referring to her cousin the barrister.
column3: Have you seen Frank, lately? said Lady Eustace, referring to her cousin the barrister.

column2: Not for ever so long, said Lucy, with her cheeriest smile.
column3: Not for ever so long, said Lucy, with her cheeriest smile.

column2: He is not going to prove a false knight? asked Lady Eustace, in her lowest whisper.
column3: He is not going to prove a false knight? asked Lady Eustace, in her lowest whisper.

column2: I don't know that Mr. Greystock is much given to knighthood at all, said Lucy,--"unless it is to being made Sir Francis by his party."
column3: I don't know that mr Greystock is much given to knighthood at all, said Lucy,--"unless it is to being made Sir Francis by his party."

column2: Nonsense, my dear; as if I didn't know.	Nonsense, my dear; as if I didn't know.

column2: I suppose Lady Fawn has been interfering--like an old cat as she is."
column3: I suppose Lady Fawn has been interfering-like an old cat as she is."

column2: If you think so, you shouldn't come here.

column2: Then she has interfered, said Lady Eustace, as she got up and walked across the room, with a sweet smile to the old cat.

column2: CHAPTER IV

column2: Frank Greystock
column3: Frank Greystock

column2: Frank Greystock the barrister was the only son of the Dean of Bobsborough.
column3: Frank Greystock the barrister was the only son of the Dean of Bobsborough.

column2: Now the dean had a family of daughters,--not quite so numerous indeed as that of Lady Fawn, for there were only three of them,--and was by no means a rich man.
column3: Now the dean had a family of daughters,--not quite so numerous indeed as that of Lady Fawn, for there were only three of them,--and was by no means a rich man.

column2: Unless a dean have a private fortune, or has chanced to draw the happy lot of Durham in the lottery of deans, he can hardly be wealthy.
column3: Unless a dean have a private fortune, or has chanced to draw the happy lot of Durham in the lottery of deans, he can hardly be wealthy.

column2: At Bobsborough the dean was endowed with a large, rambling, picturesque, uncomfortable house, and with L1,500 a year.
column3: At Bobsborough the dean was endowed with a large, rambling, picturesque, uncomfortable house, and with L one thousand five hundred a year.

column2: In regard to personal property it may be asserted of all the Greystocks that they never had any.
column3: In regard to personal property it may be asserted of all the Greystocks that they never had any.

column2: They were a family of which the males would surely come to be deans and admirals, and the females would certainly find husbands.
column3: They were a family of which the males would surely come to be deans and admirals, and the females would certainly find husbands.

column2: And they lived on the good things of the world, and mixed with wealthy people.
column3: And they lived on the good things of the world, and mixed with wealthy people.

column2: But they never had any money.
column3: But they never had any money.

column2: The Eustaces always had money, and the Bishop of Bobsborough was wealthy.
column3: The Eustaces always had money, and the Bishop of Bobsborough was wealthy.

column2: The dean was a man very different from his brother the admiral, who had never paid anybody anything.
column3: The dean was a man very different from his brother the admiral, who had never paid anybody anything.

column2: The dean did pay; but he was a little slow in his payments, and money with him was never very plentiful.
column3: The dean did pay; but he was a little slow in his payments, and money with him was never very plentiful.

column2: In these circumstances it became very expedient that Frank Greystock should earn his bread early in life.
column3: In these circumstances it became very expedient that Frank Greystock should earn his bread early in life.
